title: Pursuing the clash of incompatible ideas, James Beattie
professor of Moral Philosophy and Logic at the University of Aberdeen, writes in his essay ‘On Laughter and Ludicrous Composition’
Commedia dell’arte a form of improvised comedy first recorded in Italy in 1545, and flourishing from the sixteenth to the early eighteenth

Women and Comedy: Rewriting the British Theatrical Tradition, Ann Arbor: University of Michigan Press. Excellent discussion of the role of the comic representations of women in British theatre, including feminist and political theatre of the late twentieth century
Comedy High and Low: An Introduction to the Experience of Comedy
A loosely organized collection of observations about comedy that provides valuable insight into many aspects of comic effect and technique
On Humour
An essential introduction to the philosophy of humour that considers the place of the body in comedy, and the ideas of Nietzsche, Bakhtin, and Freud
Stand-Up: On Being a Comedian

Combines an autobiographical account of the author’s experience as a stand-up comedian with useful historical analysis of the rise and development of stand-up from the Victorian music hall to the present day
Women and Laughter
The leading book on its topic, an invaluable analysis of women in British and American film, television, and stand-up comedy that includes theoretical discussion of the gendered politics of laughter
Seriously Funny: From the Ridiculous to the Sublime, Harmondsworth: Viking. An historically and geographically farreaching analysis of comedy and humour’s social function
English Stage Comedy, 1490–1990, New York and London: Routledge. A very useful and comprehensive study of comic theatre organized around an analysis of recurring themes
Playboys and Killjoys: An Essay on the Theory and Practice of Comedy
Taking Laughter Seriously
A detailed analysis of concepts and trends in the philosophical discussion of humour
Taking Humour Seriously
A superb text that considers comedy and humour from a cultural and sociological perspective and treats literary examples of humour alongside analyses of joking relationships

Because I Tell a Joke or Two: Comedy, Politics and Social Difference, London and New York: Routledge. A diverse collection of essays and interviews on twentieth-century British film and television comedy
The Spectator

Dialectic of Enlightenment
